gr.forth.ics.graph
Interface InspectableGraph

All Known Subinterfaces:
Graph
All Known Implementing Classes:
FoldingGraph, GraphForwarder, InspectableGraphForwarder, PrimaryGraph, SecondaryGraph
public interface InspectableGraph

A read-only graph. A graph G = {N, E} is a set of nodes and edges. Each edge connects exactly two nodes that also belong to the same graph. That is, no edge can connect to a node that is not part of the graph.

Node and edge iterators returned reflect the most current state of the graph. That is, if a node iteration is in progress and a node, which has not been iterated yet, is removed, it will not appear at all. Similarly, a new node may or may not appear in an iteration that started before the new node addition. It is guaranteed that removed elements will not (re-)appear in iterations, after their removals (assuming single-threaded execution). Elements may, or may not, be removed through the iterators, depending on the graph implementation.

All iterator-style methods (e.g., nodes(), edges()), actually return ExtendedListIterable instances, to provide a richer set of operations, beyond simple iteration. Note that these methods return subclasses of Iterable, so they can be used in the enhanced for-loop:
for (Node node : graph.nodes()) {
...
}

Each graph can be decorated with arbitrary key-value entries through the tuple() method.
Listeners can be attached to any graph, to receive events of interest, such as additions/removals of nodes/edges, etc.

See Also:
Node, Edge

Method Detail

isEmpty

boolean isEmpty()
Returns nodeCount() == 0. Note that a graph with no nodes, cannot possibly have any edge.

nodeCount

int nodeCount()
Returns the number of nodes contained in this graph (and returned by nodes method).

edgeCount

int edgeCount()
Returns the number of edge contained in this graph (and returned by edges method).

edges

ExtendedListIterable<Edge> edges()
Returns an ExtendedListIterable over all edges of this graph.

nodes

ExtendedListIterable<Node> nodes()
Returns an ExtendedListIterable over all nodes of this graph.

edges

ExtendedListIterable<Edge> edges(Node node)
Returns an ExtendedListIterable over all edges that contain the specified node. This is equivalent to edges(node, Direction.EITHER)

Parameters:
node - the node that all the returned edges must contain
Throws:
IllegalArgumentException - when !containsNode(node)

edges

ExtendedListIterable<Edge> edges(Node node,
                                 Direction direction)
Returns an ExtendedListIterable over all edges that contain the specified node at the specified direction. That is, return every edge e, when direction is:
  • Direction.OUT, such that e.n1() == node
  • Direction.IN, such that e.n2() == node
  • Direction.EITHER, such that e.isIncident(node)

    • Parameters:
    node - the node that all the returned edges must contain
    direction - specifies the direction of the returned edge, relatively to the specified node
    Throws:
    IllegalArgumentException - when !containsNode(node)
    gr.forth.ics.util.NullArgumentException - when direction is null

    edges

    ExtendedListIterable<Edge> edges(Node n1,
                                 Node n2)
    Returns an ExtendedListIterable over all edges that connect the specified nodes, in either direction. This is equivalent to edges(n1, n2, Direction.EITHER).

    Throws:
    IllegalArgumentException - when !containsNode(n1) or !containsNode(n2)

    edges

    ExtendedListIterable<Edge> edges(Node n1,
                                 Node n2,
                                 Direction direction)
    Returns an ExtendedListIterable over all edges that connect the specified nodes, in the specified direction. That is, return every edge e, when direction is:
  • Direction.OUT, such that e.n1() == n1 && e.n2() == n2
  • Direction.IN, such that e.n2() == n1 && e.n1() == n2
  • Direction.EITHER, such that e.isIncident(n1) && e.isIncident(n2)

    • Throws:
    IllegalArgumentException - when !containsNode(n1) or !containsNode(n2)
    gr.forth.ics.util.NullArgumentException - when direction is null

    adjacentNodes

    ExtendedListIterable<Node> adjacentNodes(Node node)
    Returns an ExtendedListIterable over all nodes that are neighbors with the specified node. Two nodes are "neighbors" if there exists an edge connecting the two. Actually, for every incident edge, a neighbor is reported, so in the case of parallel edges, neighbors are reported multiple times. This is equivalent to adjacentNodes(node, Direction.EITHER)

    Throws:
    IllegalArgumentException - when !containsNode(node)
    See Also:
    adjacentNodes(Node, Direction)

    adjacentNodes

    ExtendedListIterable<Node> adjacentNodes(Node node,
                                         Direction direction)
    Returns an ExtendedListIterable over all nodes that are neighbors with the specified node, in the specified direction. Two nodes are "neighbors" if there exists an edge connecting the two. Actually, for every incident edge, a neighbor is reported, so in the case of parallel edges, neighbors are reported multiple times. See edges(Node, Direction) method for the semantics of the Direction parameter.

    Parameters:
    node - the node of which the neighbors are returned
    direction - the direction in which to seek neighbors
    Throws:
    IllegalArgumentException - when !containsNode(node)
    gr.forth.ics.util.NullArgumentException - when direction is null

    areAdjacent

    boolean areAdjacent(Node n1,
                    Node n2)
    Returns whether there exists an edge connecting the specified nodes. This is equivalent to areAdjacent(n1, n2, Direction.EITHER)

    Throws:
    IllegalArgumentException - when !containsNode(n1) or !containsNode(n2)
    See Also:
    areAdjacent(Node, Node, Direction)

    areAdjacent

    boolean areAdjacent(Node n1,
                    Node n2,
                    Direction direction)
    Returns whether there exists an edge connecting the specified nodes, with the specified direction. That is, to return true there must be an edge e such that:
  • If direction is Direction.OUT, e.n1() == n1 && e.n2() == n2
  • If direction is Direction.IN, e.n2() == n1 && e.n1() == n2
  • If direction is Direction.EITHER, e.isIncident(n1) && e.isIncident(n2)

    • Throws:
    IllegalArgumentException - when !containsNode(n1) or !containsNode(n2)
    gr.forth.ics.util.NullArgumentException - when direction is null
    See Also:
    areAdjacent(Node, Node, Direction)

    Convenient method that returns an edge of this graph.

    Throws:
    NoSuchElementException - when edgeCount() == 0
    See Also:

    containsEdge

    boolean containsEdge(Edge edge)
    Returns whether this graph contains the specified edge. If edge is null, false is returned.

    containsNode

    boolean containsNode(Node node)
    Returns whether this graph contains the specified node. If node is null, false is returned.

    inDegree

    int inDegree(Node node)
    Returns the in-degree of the specified node.

    Throws:
    IllegalArgumentException - when !containsNode(node)

    outDegree

    int outDegree(Node node)
    Returns the out-degree of the specified node.

    Throws:
    IllegalArgumentException - when !containsNode(node)

    degree

    int degree(Node node)
    Returns the degree of the specified node.

    Throws:
    IllegalArgumentException - when !containsNode(node)

    degree

    int degree(Node node,
           Direction direction)
    Returns the degree of the specified node, depending on direction:
  • Direction.OUT: equivalent to outDegree(node)
  • Direction.IN: equivalent to inDegree(node)
  • Direction.EITHER: equivalent to degree(node)

    • Throws:
    IllegalArgumentException - when !containsNode(node)
    NullArgumentException - when direction == null
